clinical_study.brief_title: Stepping Stones and Creating Futures Intervention Trial
clinical_study.official_title: Stepping Stones and Creating Futures Intervention Trial

collaborator.agency: London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine
Department for International Development, United Kingdom

brief_summary.textblock: This study evaluates whether the behavioural/structural interventions of Stepping Stones and Creating Futures can reduce the incidence of intimate partner violence in urban informal settlements amongst young people. Half the participants will receive the interventions, while the other half will be in a control wait-list, only receiving the intervention after final data collection.

primary_outcome.measure: Any past year physical intimate partner violence perpetration (men) and experience (women)
primary_outcome.description: Physical intimate partner violence is assessed using five items based on the WHO VAW scale. A positive response to any item leads to a person being classified as perpetrating (men) and experiencing (women) in the past year.

primary_outcome.measure: Any past year sexual intimate partner violence perpetration (men) and experience (women)
primary_outcome.description: Sexual intimate partner violence is assessed using three items based on the WHO VAW scale assessing past year experience. A positive response to any item leads to a person being classified as perpetrating (men) and experiencing (women) in the past year.

primary_outcome.measure: Past year severe sexual and/or physical intimate partner violence perpetration (men) and experience (women)
primary_outcome.description: Severe sexual and/or physical intimate partner violence perpetration (men) and experience (women) is assessed using 8 items. Past year severe sexual and/or physical IPV is assessed as positive if a person responds to two (or more) items as once, or one item as few (or more), essentially creating a more than once categorization.

Controlling behaviours are assessed using a modified Sexual Relationship Power (SRP) scale. Men's control of female sexual partner's and women's experience of controlling behaviours from a male partner. A mean score is calculated.
A single item question asks "Considering all the money you earned from jobs or selling things (excluding grants), how much did you earn last month?" Responses are in Rands and a continuous scale.

secondary_outcome.description: Modified gender equitable men's scale assess participant's gender attitudes. A mean score is calculated.
Past week depressive symptomology is assessed by the Centre for Epidemiological Studies Depression (CESD) scale, with the full twenty items. A mean score will be calculated.
Past four week suicidal ideation is assessed using a single item question and a binary yes/no response.
Four items modified from the satisfaction with life scale. Mean score calculated.
Problem drinking in the past year is assessed using the AUDIT scale. A score of 8 or more classifies a participant as having potentially problematic alcohol use.
A single item binary response question asks whether participants have argued about alcohol with their sexual partner in the past year.
A single item assess who the participant last had sex with. Categorised into a binary response as either "main partner" or "other" with other comprising "casual, once-off, ex-partner".
Five item scale asks about transactional sex with casual or once-off sexual partners in the past year. A response of yes to any is classified as having engaged in transactional sex.
Four items assess participants' feelings of shame about not enough work. Mean score calculated.
Four items assess participants' feelings of stress about not enough work. Mean score calculated.

secondary_outcome.measure: Mobilisation of money in an emergency
secondary_outcome.description: Single item asks participants how hard it would be to mobilise R200 (~US$15) in an emergency. Those responding it would be "very difficult, or somewhat difficult" are classified as finding it hard. Those responding "fairly easy or easy" are classified as not finding it hard.

secondary_outcome.measure: Stealing because of hunger in past month
secondary_outcome.description: Single item question asks about stealing because of lack of food or money in the past month. Responses are reclassified into never, or once or more.

arm_group.description: Participants receive the Stepping Stones and Creating Futures intervention, comprising of 21 participatory/inter-active sessions, delivered by a trained facilitators. Each session last approximately 3 hours. Sessions are delivered twice a week. Sessions are primarily single sex, with 20 participants per group.
Participants receive no intervention until after final data collection occurs, at which point they will be offered Stepping Stones and Creating Futures.

intervention.description: Stepping Stones consists of 10 sessions. It seeks to strengthen relationships and to transform views on gender and in the process impact on exposure to, or participation in, gender-based violence and HIV risk. These cover gender and peer influences our actions; sex and love; conception and contraception; STIs and HIV; safer sex and condoms; GBV; motivations for behaviour (including influences of alcohol and poverty); and communication skills. Creating Futures is a facilitated group intervention of eleven sessions. It seeks to strengthen livelihoods. The key sessions include: setting medium term livelihood goals, the need for assets and coping with crises; social resources for livelihoods (trust and community participation); getting and keeping jobs; and savings and spending.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Normally resident in informal settlement cluster
- Not formally employed
- Able to communicate in main study languages (English, isiZulu, iXhosa)
Exclusion Criteria:
- Under 18
- Mental deficit (learning difficulty, mental illness or substance abuse)
